What are the pros and cons of a Bivy and a tent. Which one do you recommend for 1 person?

I prefer tent. ALPKIT Soloist https://alpkit.com/products/soloist
Soloist 1-person backpacking tent
alpkit.com
data.author: Gedas Rasa Kaval

data.text: I've got one, the XL, really packs small but I also use various bivvies as well.
data.author: Simon Woodward

data.text: this is how my full bikepack looks.
data.author: Gedas Rasa Kaval

data.text: which bag do you use on the top bar?
data.author: Sarah Dee

data.text: I use POD sacks from Planet X. I like soloist because the poles are compact folded up so I pop them in my frame bag. The inner, outer and footprint fold up really small. Took a couple of trips to get used to the narrow design but loads of headroom which is good because I am 6'3" and old! Wouldn't want to be high winds up on open hills but then I'd be hiking not biking if I was doing that, then I use either a Snugpak Ionosphere or Coleman Cobra.
data.author: Simon Woodward
Simon Woodward
Simon Woodward

data.text: This is my lighter overnight set up using a tarp and bivvy, this is my adventure bike the other is a road bike, as you can see I can get away with the smaller saddle bag.
data.author: Simon Woodward

data.text: This is a road bike I built for longer distances, it's good for 60 miles rides between camps and is pretty comfortable. I've used stronger wheels and 28mm tyres, it's on a 11-34 on a sub compact 46-34 Shimano 105 groupset. This set up gives me good climbing plus a useful top end still.
data.author: Simon Woodward

data.text: both look very impressive! Many wonderful bikepacking experiences I'm guessing?
data.author: Sarah Dee

data.text: no quite new to it but not hiking or biking just never mixed the two until last year. I thought I knew what I was doing until I did my first a year ago, getting the weight down wasn't to tricky as I have good hiking kit but getting the bulk down was the biggest challenge. Since then I've done a fair few trips and each time I learn something new. Getting the weight low and in the middle of the bike helps a lot. Quite like the POD kit is cheap, well made and waterproof but a tad heavy. I do a lot of bivvy camping anyway so use to using tarps, it's a good option a 3.0 X 2.9 DD Superlight is under 500 grams and very compact but cost around 70 quid then you will need a pole unless you can use a tree. Then you need a ground sheet and bivvy so this soon makes it the same weight as the soloist if not more but loads of room. This is my DD Superlight with a Alpkit Hunka bivvy, this was last November on a very wet weekend in The Peaks, works well.
data.author: Simon Woodward

data.text: does this mean you have an open entrance to all the elements?
data.author: Sarah Dee

data.text: that set in the picture is but if you look up "Making a Tarp Tent" on YouTube then that will show a design with a more closed up front, still open but not as much. In that picture what you can see is the front is up against a hedgerow which blocks the wind. This was on an out of season campsite still open but mainly for camper vans. We ended up on our own but still had the facilities designed for hundreds of people which was useful as we just needed a base camp so we could go off exploring the area off road.
data.author: Simon Woodward

data.text: I prefer a tent... After long day in the saddle, i prefer to sleep not worrying about bugs, crawlies, rain, etc. I might include an ultralight hammock in the future, if nights are too hot, only have to find one with acceptable weight and bug mesh. I use Lanshan 1 tent. Pros are weight, simplicity, protection, price, packed size. Cons - a bit tight inside (no place for gear), i have to carry a trekking pole or similar to pitch it. If i could afford a freestanding tent under or close to 1kg, I'd go for it.
data.author: Ivan Perak

data.text: A bivvy is lighter than a tent. With a tent you are much more protected from the elements and insects.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: I have a bivy that protects from insects and elements, but I can sit up and change in it and I can‚Äôt protect my gear from rain in it
data.author: Michael Moak

data.text: . What model is it? It sounds like it would take a lot of material. Would an Ultra light tent be about the same weight?
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: Typo. I CAN‚ÄôT sit up and change in it. Outdoor Research Helium Bivy. I prefer my tent at night and the bivy while carrying it during the day. Ha ha. Sorry about the typo.
data.author: Michael Moak

data.text: I have a bivvy and a tent. The tent is certainly more comfortable. But the bivvy does its job.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: I have an Alpkit soloist. It gets used in the colder months. Bivy and occasionally a tarp. If you know the weather is fair you don‚Äôt need a tarp.
data.author: Paul Tozer

data.text: I did that on my last trip; bivy plus tarp. But then I realized that the combo was barely more than a pound lighter than my super comfortable spacious tent. I either need a lighter tarp, or I‚Äôll use the tent next time.
data.author: Michael Moak

data.text: I carry this on my race bike handlebar. Naturehike 2 person tent. Also allows me to move inside. Have my bags inside etc.

data.text: just ordered the 1 person. Are the pegs that come with it sufficiently strong enough?
data.author: Sarah Dee

data.text: Naturehike company does amazing camping staff. I've got matt, towels, small waterproof folding backpack and few more things. The quality, design and the innovation level is impressive.
data.author: Dan Alec

data.text: Front is actually two bags. One roll with tent. Baselayer for tent and sleeping pad and a smaller one that attaches to it for food etc. Rhino walk is the brand. Set from Amazon.
data.author: Stefan Lehnertz

data.text: Both bags full on this picture. Got a tri bar now to strap them down better to get them higher. Might not work well on smaller frames. I have a 58cm frame
data.author: Stefan Lehnertz

data.text: pegs are durable enough.
data.author: Stefan Lehnertz

data.text: what is the idea of panniers on the front forks and keeping the eritht low down? Does the weight higher up affect your steering at all?
data.author: Sarah Dee

data.text: Took a bit to get used to it plus one doesn't see the front wheel. Due to carbon fork I couldn't mount panniers. I'd prefer that though if possible
data.author: Stefan Lehnertz

data.text: bikepacking bags set up is the best for me. Panniers are not good for off road conditions and they get dirty very easily. They need extra racks /weight which is not good for ultralight bikepacking. Its good to have a small foldable waterproof backpack just in case you get an extra luggage or shopping. End of the day it's all about the adventure. Any bike and any set up is good if you love bikepacking and the nature. üòâ
data.author: Dan Alec

data.text: I like both a tent and a bivvy for different types of weather. Bivvies are more stealth and don‚Äôt need pegs so I‚Äôve slept a wide range of places (roadside reserves to a Seawall at the foot of a castle). Tents I prefer in rainy weather.
data.author: Darren Hocking

data.text: i think you have hit the nail on the head. A tent us preferable, rain, misqitos, etc. but a bivi can go places, but you cant easily get dressed in one. When it comes the weight my tent is lighter at 480g than my bivi

data.author: Dale Tan

data.text: Depends how much sleep you like to take. Short and sharp BIvvy is great. If you like to sleep long, through weather and protected against visitors as well as having a private change room tent is perfect.
data.author: Jodi Brown

data.text: Both. I have a single tent and a bivy bag that‚Äôs a simple fairly water resistant bag. And a hammock. Ya never know what you are going to do for the night.
data.author: Don Stewart

data.text: Love my highside by sierria designs üíï Yes I'm scrunched up to the door for a photo I'm 5 10 and plenty of room

data.text: Love my klymit traverse too :)
data.author: Donovan Jannaway

data.text: Some modern one person tents are so light that they weight just as much as a bivalve which to me makes bivys obsolete. My latest tent weights just 2.4 pounds or about 1200 grams.
data.author: Andrew Besold

data.text: but when you‚Äôre trying to stay under the radar it‚Äôs easier with a bivy.
data.author: Paul Tozer

data.text: good point. I‚Äôve stealth camped a few nights in that tent and with its dark green rainfly it seems pretty stealthy.

data.author: Keith Estrera

data.text: No poles make a bivy lighter right off the bat.
data.author: Kenneth Samuel Cromie

data.text: Tent.
data.author: Garry Joseph

data.text: Pros of a tent: More room. You can put some of your gear inside in case of bad weather You can size up if you feel like (e.g. a small two person tent makes for a really spacious single person tent) Rain fly is usually separate which means you can open up your tent for nice airflow on hot nights Cons of a tent: It‚Äôs more fabric so it will be heavier The ultra light versions can cost a lot of money Almost always have longer poles and more poles, so a bit hard to pack down Longer set up time Pros of a bivy: Packs down to nothing Cheaper Lighter Faster to set up and break down Cons of a bivy Typically no separate rain fly, they can be stuffy on a hot night Not everyone can get used to tight quarters No room for your gear inside Everything above is mostly a fact, not really subject to opinions. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll get some debate about it. As far as what people pick will be a matter of opinion. Personally, I like a bivy for bikepack racing or for a short trip in nice weather. On the other hand, if I‚Äôm gonna be out there a while and have the potential of facing some inclement weather, my tent is coming with me and bivy stays home. Good luck!
data.author: Miro Rakic

data.text: If its really hot - you just need a mat and a lightweight bag....
data.author: Sel Dixon

data.text: bivis are great for 1 night lightweight and stealth camping. Sleeping bags will get wet in the most breathable bivi....your body produces moisture as you sleep, not just your mouth. So unless you want to spend time drying your bag each day.....mutli day trips are better with a tent. Also weather forecasts are are generally good 2-3 days out, so you can estimate if a bivi will be fine....but for multli-day, even a long weekend the additional rain protection of a tent for equipment and cooking under is better. Tents are better for base camping, where you are basing your self in one place and cycling out each day. Tents are also better protection from biting insects.....bivi's can give protection if you are reading or sleeping.....but it is less easy, doable just less easy, to eat in a bivi. I once spent an evening running around my bivi bag trying to avoid the insects whilst I had my dinner....that I had to cook in the open surrounded by the varmits.
data.author: Graeme Thomson
